title: Problem Overview
mathContext: This is a problem about finding sets C in (n, 2n) such that no two distinct elements sum to something in a forbidden set B ⊂ (2n, 4n).

title: Interval Definitions
content:
**lowerInterval and upperInterval:**

- (n, 2n) ∩ ℕ: natural numbers strictly between n and 2n
- (2n, 4n) ∩ ℕ: natural numbers strictly between 2n and 4n

Key observation: if c₁, c₂ ∈ (n, 2n), then c₁ + c₂ ∈ (2n, 4n).

title: Sum-Free with Respect to B
content:
**isSumFreeWithResp C B:**

C is sum-free with respect to B if no two distinct elements c₁, c₂ ∈ C have c₁ + c₂ ∈ B.

This is NOT the same as C being sum-free - we only forbid sums that land in B.
mathContext: Unlike classical sum-free sets, here we only avoid specific forbidden sums.

title: The Function f(n)
content:
**f n:**

f(n) = max k such that ∀ B ⊆ (2n, 4n), ∃ C ⊆ (n, 2n) sum-free w.r.t. B with |C| + |B| ≥ k.

This captures the "guaranteed combined size" regardless of how B is chosen.

title: Choi's Results (1971)
Adenwalla's Lower Bound
content:
**adenwalla_lower_bound and Sidon sets:**

f(n) ≫ n^{1/2} via a simple construction using Sidon sets.

**Sidon set:** A set where all pairwise sums are distinct.

A Sidon set of size ~√n has only ~n distinct sums, leaving room in (2n, 4n) for B.
mathContext: Sidon sets control which sums appear, enabling the lower bound construction.

title: BSS Bound (2000)
Current Bounds
content:
**current_bounds and the_gap:**

**Lower:** f(n) ≫ n^{1/2} (Adenwalla)
**Upper:** f(n) ≪ (n log n)^{2/3} (BSS 2000)

**The Gap:** The exponent is between 1/2 and 2/3. Choi's conjecture says it should be 1/2 + o(1).

title: Classical Sum-Free Sets
content:
**isSumFree S:**

A set S is sum-free if a + b ∉ S for all a, b ∈ S.

This problem generalizes: instead of avoiding all sums landing in S, we avoid sums landing in a prescribed set B.
